contextId.information: The phrase "to pass through the fire" means to burn something with fire as a sacrifice. AT: "You must not burn your children alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: You must not give any of your children to put them into the fire

contextId.information: The phrase "set my face against" is an idiom which means "to reject" or "to oppose strongly." AT: "I will also reject him" or "I will also oppose him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I also will set my face against that man

contextId.information: This phrase means the man is responsibile for his sin. AT: "He is responsible for his sin" or "You must punish him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "flowing with milk and honey" means "that is rich and productive with enough food for everyone." AT: "a land that is excellent for cattle and farming" or "a productive land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: a land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.information: By marrying an unholy or ungodly woman, the priest would have children unworthy to be priest. AT: "that he will not have unworthy children by marrying an ungodly woman" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: he will not defile his children among his people

contextId.information: "Generation after generation" is an idiom that refers to each generation that lives after another. AT: "your descendants belonging to all future generations may learn" or "all your descendants may learn forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: your descendants, generation after generation, may learn

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means that one life would replace the other. AT: "one life to replace the other life" or "to replace the one that he killed" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This refers to broken bones. AT: "broken bone for broken bone" or "If he breaks someone's bone, one of his bones must be broken"  or "If he breaks someone's bone, they will break one of his bones" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This refers to teeth being knocked out of the mouth. AT: "If he knocks out someone's tooth, one of his teeth must be knocked out" or "If he knocks out someone's tooth, they will knock out one of his teeth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here bread represents food. "To the full" means until their stomachs were full of food. AT: "will eat food until you are full" or "will have plenty of food to eat" (See: [[: en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: will eat your bread to the full

contextId.information: The phrase "for nothing"  means that they would get nothing from their work. AT: "You will plant your seeds in vain" or "You will plant your seeds, but you will not get anything from them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: You will plant your seeds for nothing

contextId.information: Here "seven times" is not literal. It means Yahweh will increase the severity of his punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "seven more times" is not literal. It means Yahweh will increase the severity of his punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will punish you even seven more times as much

contextId.information: "Call to mind" is an idiom meaning "intentionally remember." Here it represents fulfilling his covenant. AT: "I will fulfill the covenant with their ancestors" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will call to mind the covenant with their ancestors
